results.title: Magnaphonic 35mm projector
results.material_description:
C&W Sydney
Magna Coustian Pty ltd
41 Riley Street, Sydney

Magnaphonic full range sound system
manufactured by:
Magna Coustian Pty ltd
41 Riley Street, Sydney
Phone FL 1322
Phone FL 2554

ID. 8077
The British Thomson, Houston Co.  Ltd
Rugby, England (Made in England)
A.C. Motor
Type BKS 2408
HP 1/4
R.P.M: 1425
Volts 240/250
Cycles 50
Phase 1
Rating: Continuous
Cat no. D877416

The top case has a blue plastic reel with film inside it.
The bottom case has a red plastic reel inside it.
There is an orange rubber power cord nestled and rolled up in the middle of the unit.

Adjustments:  there is black duct tape holding in place a small box.  The unit has very much been modified by the previous owner.

Condition:
The rubber belt has begun to erode and crack, the belt behind that has also begun to erode.
There is black paint flecking away, particularly towards to top.
results.brief_description: One of two magnaphonic 35mm projectors donated by Bill Newman. Kerri’s father (name to be confirmed) has taken the projectors apart, cleaned them and re-assembled them. He has also repainted the lamp houses. Representative of early twentieth century Australian cinema equipment and history. These projectors were operated in Tumbarumba NSW, by William James Burnell Newman (Bill), who operated under Valley Theatres, from approximately 1959 until 1965, when TV started the demise of country theatres. These projectors were used in tandem as film rolls needed to be changed seamlessly during a session. The projectionist loaded all ‘even’ reels on one projector, and ‘odd’ reels on the other projector. As a reel was nearing its end, the projectionist had to switch over the film with perfect timing.

results.title: The Telegram Man
results.creator_credit: James Khehtie, Ceinwen Berry and Victoria Wharfe McIntyre
results.brief_description: Multi-award-winning film ‘The Telegram Man’ poignantly depicts the human cost of war in its portrayal of relationships impacted by the vicissitudes of wartime. Featuring restrained but deeply emotional performances from some of Australia’s finest screen actors (Jack Thompson, Gary Sweet and Sigrid Thornton), this is a powerful film about loss, grief and duty.

results.title: anywhere and here
results.credit_line:
Ian Burns
mixed media installation
ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
‘anywhere and here’ is a suite of five interconnected kinetic sculptures which generate their own real-time video. It specifically explores the road movie genre, summoning familiar visions of the empty landscape, the wide open road and the car-in-motion, to destabilise powerful cinematic clichés.

‘anywhere and here’ was commissioned by ACMI and was exhibited at ACMI as “Ian Burns: In the Telling” in 2012-13.

Burns adapts existing appliances and domestic items and gives them new functions within his sculptures. This work draws meaning from the contrast between the projected image and the machinery out of which it is made.

The five sculptures that make up this work are linked via a video control system constructed by Burns and designed to switch between each of the structures at random. The images that are produced by the sculptures are projected onto the wall for the audience to view. Each scene generates its own live soundtrack. Burns has hacked an electronic keyboard to plunk out a simple music track. The keyboard becomes an integral part of the sculpture.

A shot of the moon suspended over water is based around a glass top table. The resulting optic effect simulates water movement and sparkle. A strip of plywood simulates the sky at dusk, while the moon is created by the projection of light through a hole in the wood.

On one end of a folding table the effect of a smoking chimney is generated using a plastic salad bowl with a LED light inside shining through a slit cut in the backing of a picture frame. The view from the camera is across a roll of hobby store brick print paper.

On the other end of the folding table, to simulate a high zoom shot of a plane passing overhead, Burns rotates a party store plastic salad bowl while a LED light inside the bowl generates the cloud effect. A fan usually used as a cooling device for a computer, generates the sound of the jet and shakes the camera to simulate the zoom effect on a hand-held camera.

A black vinyl chair has been stripped of all its vinyl until only a narrowing strip remains with slots cut out of it. The camera view of this under a red light gives it the look of a remote roadway in dry country.

The shot in close-up of a wheel with the white stripes of the road whizzing past is a road movie cliché. The sculpture is constructed out of an actual car wheel on a treadmill and a camera positioned to catch a cinematic view of the action.

The fifth sculpture comprises the central electronic system that guides the work as a whole.

results.title: Type 2014K Image Orthicon camera
results.creator_credit: Films & Equipment Ltd., PYE Ltd. and Vinten
results.brief_description: Pye cameras were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.

constellations_primary.name: News on location
constellations_primary.description: The Pye Orthicon is an example of the type of television cameras used from the 1950s in Australia for both studio and outside broadcast work. Such cameras did not have have the capacity to record while out on location and so outside crews would transmit vision and sound back to studios for recording or live broadcast.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Films & Equipment Ltd., PYE Ltd. and Vinten
results.description:
In 1948, Australian audiences were introduced to television at the Sydney Royal Easter Show. The British electronics company Pye had brought its 405-line cameras and monitors to encourage interest in the new medium.

While it would be eight years until Bruce Gyngell famously welcomed Australia to television, the Pye company was still essential to the burgeoning industry.

Pye cameras like this were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.
description_for_label:

Pye cameras like this were used across Australia in newsrooms and in the field by journalists at GTV9 and ABV2. They are lightweight and compact, making them easy to transport, and they feature an extended focus range switch for extreme close-ups.

results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.

results.title: Platform 1
results.brief_description: As a visitor descends the stairway into the Screen Gallery, her path will leave a trace through which imagery will emerge from the past — people ascending from a train platform in Australia one hundred years ago. The artwork is a live interplay between the present and the past. As ACMI visitors descend the stairs to encounter the future of screen arts, they pass through the lingering and ever-present influence of cinematic history. A wondrous, benign space of haunting, the staircase initiates Screen Gallery visitors into the ever-present power of cinematic history.

results.title: Hold: Vessel #1 and Vessel #2
results.material_description: mixed media, interactive video, projection, glass, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
Hold: Vessel 1 is a magical interactive experience in which visitors to the gallery try to catch a mesmerizing series of projected visions in a delicate glass bowl - echoing the wondrous views of the world made possible with the first microscopes, underwater cameras and astronomical cinematography.
Lynette Wallworth began her career in photography, and has also worked in short film, installation and performance. She creates installation spaces that require activation by the participant/viewer. To collect the images used in Hold: Vessel 1 she collaborated with scientific image libraries and specialist cinematographers, as part of her ongoing investigation into imaging technologies that enable us to see the world in ways otherwise inaccessible to the naked human eye. Hold: Vessel 1 consists of video projections with directional sound scape beamed from above into a darkened space. The visitor is invited to take hold of a glass bowl and catch the images within it, finding the point at which the vision is most clear and resolved. A personal portal opens to us as we cradle the bowl in our hands. Imagery in ‘Hold’ is derived mainly from Australian scientists and specialist cinematographers including: David Hannan, who has adapted medical imaging technology to film extreme macro images of the Great Barrier Reef, Anya Salih, who investigates coral fluorescence and Greg Rouse, Marine Biologist. The work is designed as a vessel to hold a changing pool of imagery. Hold: Vessel 1 will change in time as time changes the environments it reflects.

results.title: Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion [exhibition] : archival material
results.brief_description:
“Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion” was an ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 26 October 2002 - 27 January 2003.
See Exhibition activity record “Deep Space” (ID 3) for more information
The international and Australian contemporary artists in this exibition present environments, or chambers, for the visitor to participate in an all encompassing aesthetic experience. The audience is invited to move within the art works, to explore their physical construction, their digital presence, their filmic pulse and their saturated expanses of colour and light. The experiences vary: some are quiet, some intangible, others humourous or uncanny. Each involves an ephemeral medium, whether it be light, video or digital imagery and each encloses the viewer in a confined space only to offer them access to another expanded sense of space altogether. This exhibition offers visitors a memorable and transformative experience of being immersed in ‘deep space’, the kineasthetic, visual, aural and informational totality of the art works.
